awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Interpersonal Coordination and Coregulation during Collaborative Problem Solving
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative problem solving (CPS) is an essential skill in our increasingly connected and globalized world. Yet, there is a paucity of knowledge on how to define, measure, and develop this skill, especially in the context of STEM learning. A team of investigators from Notre Dame University, Florida State University, and Arizona State University will seek to discover how interpersonal interactions arise and influence CPS processes and outcomes in digital STEM learning environments. The research will focus on groups of high school and college students collaborating virtually within a STEM educational game called Physics Playground. The hypothesis is that CPS effectiveness can be improved by providing real-time automated feedback on the ongoing collaboration. The investigators will collect an array of data, ranging from individual physiological measures to learning outcome measures to group communication patterns. Their goal is to improve the design of future CPS learning environments, making them more enjoyable, engaging, and effective. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning.

The research will involve dyads and triads collaborating virtually within a learning environment called Physics Playground, a STEM educational game. Data will be collected in both the lab and classroom, using a diverse sample of high school and college students from three sites across the U.S. The team will integrate data from a range of sources including modeling of small group problem solving and collaborative learning and from the modeling of low-level data from eye tracking, facial feature tracking, psychophysiology, and linguistic/paralinguistic speech analysis. Additionally, the team will study the moderating effects of task constraints and group composition on CPS processes and outcomes. A further goal is to model dynamic CPS processes using nonlinear time series analyses and multimodal deep recurrent neural networks. The computational models will be integrated into the learning environment to test the hypothesis that CPS outcomes can be improved by providing automated feedback on unfolding collaborative processes. Thus, by blending basic experimental research, multisensor-multimodal analysis, computational modeling, and dynamic computerized intervention, the researchers will attempt to make foundational theoretical, methodological, and technological advances.

por.por_cntn:
It is the long history of humankind (and animal kind, too) that those who learned to collaborate and improvise most effectively have prevailed.  Charles Darwin

The main goal of this project is to gain basic knowledge on how interpersonal interactions influence the processes and outcomes of collaborative problem solving (CPS) in digital STEM learning contexts.  Two main sub-goals of the project on which the FSU team has focused include: (a) understanding the nature of CPS that can then be formalized into a CPS competency model, and (b) using that model to examine how CPS skills are manifested when playing STEM educational games. We additionally have been examining how various aspects of CPS contribute to game performance and STEM learning, focusing on particular CPS indicators that are evidenced by small teams during natural, human-human interactions.

The FSU team provided the game (Physics Playground; designed and developed by the FSU team) for the CPS-related studies. This comprises the main digital task (i.e., solving various levels in the game) where team members interact with the game and each other. After an extensive literature review, we came up with a CPS competency model that was subsequently refined over the course of the project, and helped to develop and then train others on a coding method.  The CPS model is described in detail here, published recently in Computers & Education.

Over the course of the project, we iteratively developed three versions of the CPS competency model. The first version was based on a theoretical review of the literature and was developed as part of prior research examining how high school students (in triads) collaborated with each other to succeed in Physics Playground. Model 1 was tailored to that particular game, and behavioral indicators of CPS (e.g., talks about specific solutions) were developed and used as the basis to code the video recordings of students' gameplay. Model 2 was developed with the aim of making Model 1 applicable to learning environments beyond Physics Playground, and was validated in two different studies. That is, we analyzed the data from the prior research involving triads playing Physics Playground, and additionally used Model 2 to code college students (in triads) playing Minecraft. In that study, we adopted a thin-slice coding method (i.e., randomly selected 90-second chunks from each 5-minute video segment). We trained coders and obtained good inter-rater reliability (Spearman's r = .92). Factor and regression analyses were used to empirically test our competency model. Both studies provided support for our generalized CPS model. The principal component analysis on indicator frequencies yielded five factors that mapped onto our theoretical model. Correlational analysis indicated that the CPS facets and sub-facets were mostly orthogonal. Moreover, the facets showed discriminant validity as they did not correlate with prior knowledge, intelligence, and personality. Importantly, the facets showed incremental predictive validity by predicting team-level task scores and individual-level posttest scores as well as subjective perceptions of the collaboration outcome controlling for covariates.

The empirical results from our preceding work, in conjunction with an updated literature review, suggested slight adjustments to the model, yielding Model 3, shown in the Table below.

TABLE. CPS facets and their indicators to analyze participants' utterances.

CPS facets

Indicators

Constructing shared knowledge

  • Talks about challenge situation
  • Proposes correct solutions
  • Proposes incorrect solutions (R)
  • Confirms understanding
  • Interrupts others. (R)

Negotiation/Coordination

  • Provide reasons to support a solution
  • Questions/Corrects others' mistakes
  • Responds to others' ideas/questions
  • Discusses the results
  • Brings up giving up the challenge (R)
  • Strategizes to achieve task goals
  • Tries to quickly save almost successful attempts

Maintaining team function

  • Asks for suggestions
  • Compliments or encourage others
  • Provides instructional support
  • Apologizes for one's mistakes
  • Initiative off-topic conversation (R)
  • Joins off-topic conversation (R)

 Note: Indicators with (R) are negative indicators.

Using CPS Model 3, we subsequently investigated how various aspects of CPS contribute to different in-game performance measures, coding new data from college students (in triads) playing Physics Playground. We measured inter-rater reliability among three coders, per indicator, in various ways (i.e., Gwets AC1, percentage agreement, and incidence--all about .90). We also coded level attempts using different outcomes (i.e., success vs. failure). The purpose of this effort was to compare CPS differences as a function of successful and unsuccessful teams. CPS differences were examined at two levels: indicators (specific) and facets (general), controlling for known covariates. At the indicator level, only a portion (5/18) of the indicators significantly predicted in-game performance. However, when aggregated (from indicators into facets), all three CPS facets significantly predicted in-game performance. Both models explained 59% of the variance in our outcome. This suggests that Model 3 can accurately assess students' CPS skills in game-based learning environments. More studies are needed to investigate specific relationships between CPS skills and other outcomes, such as learning, and then use that information to provide targeted interventions to support CPS skills.
